  • 2. Documentation for the som module

2. Documentation for the som module¶

som.man_dist_pbc(m, vector, shape=(10, 10))[source]¶

Manhattan distance calculation of coordinates with periodic boundary condition

Parameters

  • m – {numpy.ndarray} array / matrix

  • vector – {numpy.ndarray} array / vector

  • shape – {tuple} shape of the SOM

Returns

{numpy.ndarray} Manhattan distance for v to m

class som.SOM(x, y, alpha_start=0.6, sigma_start=None, seed=None)[source]¶

Class implementing a self-organizing map with periodic boundary conditions. It has the following methods:

__init__(x, y, alpha_start=0.6, sigma_start=None, seed=None)[source]¶

Initialize the SOM object with a given map size

Parameters

  • x – {int} width of the map

  • y – {int} height of the map

  • alpha_start – {float} initial alpha (learning rate) at training start

  • sigma_start – {float} initial sigma (restraint / neighborhood function) at training start; if None: x / 2

  • seed – {int} random seed to use

initialize(data, how='pca')[source]¶

Initialize the SOM neurons

Parameters

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} data to use for initialization

  • how – {str} how to initialize the map, available: pca (via 4 first eigenvalues) or random (via random values normally distributed in the shape of data)

Returns

initialized map in self.map

winner(vector)[source]¶

Compute the winner neuron closest to the vector (Euclidean distance)

Parameters

vector – {numpy.ndarray} vector of current data point(s)

Returns

indices of winning neuron

cycle(vector, verbose=True)[source]¶

Perform one iteration in adapting the SOM towards a chosen data point

Parameters

  • vector – {numpy.ndarray} current data point

  • verbose – {bool} verbosity control

fit(data, epochs=0, save_e=False, interval=1000, decay='hill', verbose=True)[source]¶

Train the SOM on the given data for several iterations

Parameters

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} data to train on

  • epochs – {int} number of iterations to train; if 0, epochs=len(data) and every data point is used once

  • save_e – {bool} whether to save the error history

  • interval – {int} interval of epochs to use for saving training errors

  • decay – {str} type of decay for alpha and sigma. Choose from ‘hill’ (Hill function) and ‘linear’, with ‘hill’ having the form y = 1 / (1 + (x / 0.5) **4)

  • verbose – {bool} verbosity control

transform(data)[source]¶

Transform data in to the SOM space

Parameters

data – {numpy.ndarray} data to be transformed

Returns

transformed data in the SOM space

distance_map(metric='euclidean')[source]¶

Get the distance map of the neuron weights. Every cell is the normalised average of all distances between the neuron and all other neurons.

Parameters

metric – {str} distance metric to be used (see scipy.spatial.distance.cdist)

Returns

normalized sum of distances for every neuron to its neighbors

winner_map(data)[source]¶

Get the number of times, a certain neuron in the trained SOM is the winner for the given data.

Parameters

data – {numpy.ndarray} data to compute the winner neurons on

Returns

{numpy.ndarray} map with winner counts at corresponding neuron location

winner_neurons(data)[source]¶

For every datapoint, get the winner neuron coordinates.

Parameters

data – {numpy.ndarray} data to compute the winner neurons on

Returns

{numpy.ndarray} winner neuron coordinates for every datapoint

som_error(data)[source]¶

Calculates the overall error as the average difference between the winning neurons and the data points

Parameters

data – {numpy.ndarray}

Returns

{float} normalized error

get_neighbors(datapoint, data, labels, d=0)[source]¶

return the labels of the neighboring data instances at distance d for a given data point of interest

Parameters

  • datapoint – {numpy.ndarray} descriptor vector of the data point of interest to check for neighbors

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} reference data to compare datapoint to

  • labels – {numpy.ndarray} array of labels describing the target classes for every data point in data

  • d – {int} length of Manhattan distance to explore the neighborhood (0: same neuron as data point)

Returns

{numpy.ndarray} found neighbors (labels)

plot_point_map(data, targets, targetnames, filename=None, colors=None, markers=None, colormap='gray', example_dict=None, density=True, activities=None)[source]¶

Visualize the som with all data as points around the neurons

Parameters

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} data to visualize with the SOM

  • targets – {list/array} array of target classes (0 to len(targetnames)) corresponding to data

  • targetnames – {list/array} names describing the target classes given in targets

  • filename – {str} optional, if given, the plot is saved to this location

  • colors – {list/array} optional, if given, different classes are colored in these colors

  • markers – {list/array} optional, if given, different classes are visualized with these markers

  • colormap – {str} colormap to use, select from matplolib sequential colormaps

  • example_dict – {dict} dictionary containing names of examples as keys and corresponding descriptor values as values. These examples will be mapped onto the density map and marked

  • density – {bool} whether to plot the density map with winner neuron counts in the background

  • activities – {list/array} list of activities (e.g. IC50 values) to use for coloring the points accordingly; high values will appear in blue, low values in green

Returns

plot shown or saved if a filename is given

plot_density_map(data, colormap='gray', filename=None, example_dict=None, internal=False)[source]¶

Visualize the data density in different areas of the SOM.

Parameters

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} data to visualize the SOM density (number of times a neuron was winner)

  • colormap – {str} colormap to use, select from matplolib sequential colormaps

  • filename – {str} optional, if given, the plot is saved to this location

  • example_dict – {dict} dictionary containing names of examples as keys and corresponding descriptor values as values. These examples will be mapped onto the density map and marked

  • internal – {bool} if True, the current plot will stay open to be used for other plot functions

Returns

plot shown or saved if a filename is given

plot_class_density(data, targets, t=1, name='actives', colormap='gray', example_dict=None, filename=None)[source]¶

Plot a density map only for the given class

Parameters

  • data – {numpy.ndarray} data to visualize the SOM density (number of times a neuron was winner)

  • targets – {list/array} array of target classes (0 to len(targetnames)) corresponding to data

  • t – {int} target class to plot the density map for

  • name – {str} target name corresponding to target given in t

  • colormap – {str} colormap to use, select from matplolib sequential colormaps

  • example_dict – {dict} dictionary containing names of examples as keys and corresponding descriptor values as values. These examples will be mapped onto the density map and marked

  • filename – {str} optional, if given, the plot is saved to this location

Returns

plot shown or saved if a filename is given

plot_distance_map(colormap='gray', filename=None)[source]¶

Plot the distance map after training.

Parameters

  • colormap – {str} colormap to use, select from matplolib sequential colormaps

  • filename – {str} optional, if given, the plot is saved to this location

Returns

plot shown or saved if a filename is given

plot_error_history(color='orange', filename=None)[source]¶

plot the training reconstruction error history that was recorded during the fit

Parameters

  • color – {str} color of the line

  • filename – {str} optional, if given, the plot is saved to this location

Returns

plot shown or saved if a filename is given

save(filename)[source]¶

Save the SOM instance to a pickle file.

Parameters

filename – {str} filename (best to end with .p)

Returns

saved instance in file with name filename

load(filename)[source]¶

Load a SOM instance from a pickle file.

Parameters

filename – {str} filename (best to end with .p)

Returns

updated instance with data from filename
